sections.heading: Python Numbers
sections.description: There are three numeric types in Python: Variables of numeric types are created when you assign a value to them: To verify the type of any object in Python, use the type() function:

»»# int

sections.heading: Int
sections.description: Int, or integer, is a whole number, positive or negative, without decimals, of unlimited length.

code_blocks.code:
x = 1
y = 35656222554887711
z =
»»-3255522

print(type(x))
print(type(y))
print(type(z))

sections.heading: Float
sections.description: Float, or "floating point number" is a number, positive or negative, containing one or more decimals. Float can also be scientific numbers with an "e" to indicate the power of 10.

code_blocks.code:
x = 1.10
y = 1.0
z = -35.59

print(type(x))
print(type(y))
print(type(z))

sections.heading: Type Conversion
sections.description: You can convert from one type to another with the int(), float(), and complex() methods:

code_blocks.notes: Convert from one type to another:
code_blocks.code:
x = 1    # int
y = 2.8  # float
z = 1j   # complex

#convert from int to float:

»»a = float(x)

#convert from float to int:

»»b = int(y)

#convert from int to complex:

print(a)
print(b)

»»print(c)

print(type(a))
print(type(b))

sections.heading: Random Number
sections.description: Python does not have a random() function to make a random number, but Python has a built-in module called random that can be used to make random numbers: In our Random Module Reference you will learn more about the Random module.
